newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Newly-discovered Mondriaan to be sold at auction.
newsitem.headline: Newly-discovered Mondriaan to be sold at auction.

text.p: A lost watercolour by Dutch artist Piet Mondriaan, discovered by chance in May, will go up for auction in Amsterdam next month, Christies the auctioneers said on Friday.

The pastel-tinted picture of a blue chrysanthemum, one of several watercolours Mondriaan painted in the mid-1920s for 50 guilders a time to cover his living expenses, is expected to fetch between 80,000 and 120,000 guilders ($47,000-$71,000), Christies said. The picture was returned to the Netherlands from the United States, where it had hung unrecognised in the home of a woman from Mondriaan's home town of Amersfoort who emigrated in 1964.
After she died the watercolour went to her sister, who thought it might be a Mondriaan after seeing his work in leaflets put out by the Mondriaanhuis Museum.

Also going under the hammer in Christies' December 10 auction of modern art is the collection of Kees Groenendijk, the Dutch "artists' dentist" whose patients included leading post-war Dutch artists such as Karel Appel and Lucebert.
